title: Brexit news latest: John Bercow to ask EU for extension if asked by Parliament
text:
John Bercow has said he will send a letter to the EU asking for a Brexit extension if Parliament asks him to do so.

The Speaker made the comments after Prime Minister Boris Johnson suffered a bruising defeat in a key vote in Parliament this afternoon.

MPs voted by 322 to 306 in favour an amendment by Sir Oliver Letwin to withhold approval of the Prime Minister’s Brexit deal until legislation to implement it is put in place.

The amendment was intended to force the Prime Minister to comply with the Benn Act requiring him to seek a Brexit extension in a letter to the EU.

However, a defiant Boris Johnson told the Commons: “I will not negotiate a delay with the EU, and neither does the law compel me to do so.”

Boris Johnson speaks inside the House of Commons (AP) More

Downing Street refused to explain whether the Prime Minister will send a letter to the EU.

Asked if he would sign the letter instead, Speaker Bercow said: “If I were instructed by this House – I would do as instructed. If I were instructed or directed by a court I would do as directed. That is my instinctive reaction…I would take advice.”

He was responding to a question from SNP MP Joanna Cherry who led a major challenge against the prorogation of Parliament.

She said: “Under the law of the land [the Prime Minister] should be retreating to Number 10 to pen a letter to the European Union in terms of the act…fortunately we are back in court on Monday morning. It will be possible then to secure the court’s assistance if the Prime Minister has flouted the law and the promises he gave to the court.”

Asked if the Prime Minister would send the letter, a No10 source said: “You heard the PM’s words. We are not going to add anything.”

Mr Johnson insisted that he was not "daunted or dismayed" by the result and remained committed to taking Britain out by October 31.

Asked if previous statements from ministers that the Government would comply with the law still stood, the Prime Minister's official spokesman told a Westminster briefing: "Governments comply with the law."

MPs in the House of Commons (UK PARLIAMENT/AFP via Getty Imag) More

Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn warned Mr Johnson that he could not ignore the provisions of the Benn Act, saying: "The Prime Minister must now comply with the law. He can no longer use the threat of a no-deal crash-out to blackmail members to support his sell-out deal."

The SNP leader at Westminster Ian Blackford said that if Mr Johnson acted as if we was "above the law", he would find himself in court.

Liberal Democrat leader Jo Swinson said: "The most urgent thing right now is the Prime Minister complies with the law.”
